subject: Economics
title: Why Popcorn Costs $10 at the Movies
description: A quick win: understand Why Popcorn Costs $10 at the Movies.

hook.text: A bag of popcorn costs 20 cents to make and sells for $10 at the cinema. That's a 4,900% markup. Why would anyone pay?

buildup.text: Movie theaters make almost nothing on ticket sales â€” studios take 70-80% of the ticket price.

discovery.text: Expensive popcorn is a clever pricing strategy.

twist.text: If theaters charged $20 tickets and $3 popcorn, fewer people would come.

climax.text: Movie theaters aren't in the movie business. They're in the snack business with a movie problem.

punchline.text: The movie gets you in the door. The popcorn pays the rent.

quiz.question: Why do movie theaters charge high prices for popcorn?
options: Studios take most ticket revenue, so theaters depend on concession profits to survive
